body: @edenhill @junrao Thank you both for the reviews. I have updated the docs and added a section in protocol.html. Please let me know if more details should be added.
The clean-ups are fine, but neither of the two files changed are `KafkaConsumer`.

@ijuma It is Kafka Consumer internals. 
@Ishiihara Perhaps adding Internals to the PR title will make it more clear.
News?

This looks related to #1269. In that pull request @peterableda was changing the regex due to a challenge parsing ports with IPv6 support. The most relevant comment is [here](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1269#discussion_r61752746). Just an FYI in case some coordination is needed between the patches.
@granthenke I know that (obviously). :) I was suggesting that we can make the PR title (and hence commit message) clearer. Something like `MINOR: Clean up of ConsumerCoordinator and PartitonAssignor`

@soumyajit-sahu, I agree that it would be nicer to use a third-party library that did it all for us. However, the Kafka project is very strict about adding any dependency to the `clients` module. So, I don't think we can do that.

Having thought about this some more, I think it's OK to include the PR as is. The additional complexity in the regex is probably not worth it. We already allow some invalid IPs by having a single regex for both IPv4 and IPv6.

Can you please update the PR title to:

``` text
KAFKA-3448: Support zone index in IPv6 regex
```

And edit the PR description to be:

``` text
When an address is written textually, the zone index is appended to the address, separated by a percent sign (%). The actual syntax of zone indices depends on the operating system.
```

Once your contribution is merged, the commit title will be the PR title and the commit message will be the PR description (and hence why it's important to make them specific and descriptive).

Once you do that, I'll merge the PR.

LGTM.

@guozhangwang : Could you take a look, too, please?
@rajinisivaram : Thanks for the patch. LGTM
LGTM, thanks!
LGTM
LGTM

Thanks for the changes, @ijuma. +1, LGTM.

LGTM overall. I'm indeed concerned about the time taken for these tests, as we are addung about one minute into the unit test suite.

A couple of things we can do as follow-ups: 1) once https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1264 is merged, we can use a mock producer / consumer in Kafka Streams and check directly in the mock producers to check if the expected data was sent, and remove the embedded kafka cluster.

2) With the mock producer we can also use `waitUntil` to wait for the expected number of records to be sent, and hence get rid of the sleeping.
@guozhangwang I reduced the sleep time quite a bit. Will follow up once other PRs are in. Thanks.

Thanks for the PR, I left a minor comment, looks good otherwise. Can you please update the PR description to mention that this only happens with the old consumer (the PR description becomes the commit message)? With the new consumer (which only `ConsumerGroupCommand` supports), the NPE should not happen.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

@ijuma Do you have time to take a look? Thanks!

@guozhangwang @gwenshap Can either of you review this minor issue I found while testing KAFKA-3654? Bad config values can result in, e.g, an INT type returning null, and the validator wasn't checking this. Also added a test for the ValidString validator, but it already worked ok. This was causing NPEs that resulted in 500s from the Connect REST API instead of useful validation error messages.

Double commit would be nice as this is very low risk.
@ewencp Added unit tests. PTAL.
Thanks for the PR. The change looks good. The usual question follows: can we include a test please?
LGTM

LGTM. We have a bit of technical debt in duplicating code in the test that we could probably just reuse from the validation code, but I'm not sure its worth jumping through hoops to do that since the AbstractHerder is already mocked out of that test and that's the code we'd need to reuse.

@ijuma It is possible to write a test case for this. But I don't feel its value is worth the extra code here in this particular case. Adding unit tests for bug fixes is useful to make sure that we will not have the same bug again in the future. And it is generally for detecting bugs that is not evident by simply looking at the code.

However, the bug fixed in this patch is really straightforward and shouldn't happen again if anyone change this method in the future. A unit test for this bug should validate that flushesInProgress is decremented in the event of InterruptedException, which is essentially testing the usage of `finally` than testing any kafka-specific logic. If we should add tests for something as straightforward as this, we should probably add test for a bunch of other methods that use `finally` to enforce something, which doesn't seem feasible. What do you think?
@ijuma thanks for reviewing. Changed PR title and refactored to use map and orElse.
@ijuma @gwenshap for reviews.

This seems fine to me, but the checkstyle docs say:

> Optionally: it is referenced in Javadoc comments. This check is on by default, but it is considered bad practice to introduce a compile time dependency for documentation purposes only. As an example, the import java.util.Date would be considered referenced with the Javadoc comment {@link Date}. The alternative to avoid introducing a compile time dependency would be to write the Javadoc comment as {@link java.util.Date}.

What do others think?

@zhuchen1018, The fact that the bug exists in the first place implies that a test is worth it. Why do you think we can't regress on this? The code could be refactored and anything can happen at that point. Unless the test is slow or particularly complex, I don't see the harm in adding it.

@jhspaybar, I agree that it's pretty tricky to write a test for this race condition. Given that the fix is simple and clearly correct, I have created a PR with your fix: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1318. The merged commit will have you as the author. Thanks!
This is a revival of #86 by @jhspaybar.
Writing a test for this race condition is difficult, so LGTM.
@benstopford, since you wrote the security upgrade tests, can you please take a look?
LGTM

I guess I'm not seeing the big deal around the compile-time dependency. 
Especially when it is limited to a single class. The overhead and risk seem minimal.

Adding a test wasn't so hard after all, so I added one. @jhspaybar, can you please take a look?

And review by @guozhangwang.

btw the corresponding ticket is KAFKA-3655, not KAFKA-3651 as the PR title suggests.
Tests passed locally (Jenkins killed the PR build after 2 hours, it seems like some of the machines in the Jenkins cluster are very slow).

@ijuma Sure, I certainly agree that it is a good principle and common to "add test for a bug". Because the fact that there is a bug indicates this is probably hard to detect. But I feel that, if we couldn't require developers who originally write these code to add test for `finally`, it probably indicates that the benefits of these tests are not worth the developer's time; if this is not worth developer's time who write the feature, then we shouldn't require contributors who fix the bug to write the test. It would be a fair rule to hold developers of the feature to no lower standard than those who help fix their code, right?

It would be good to take cost of time into account and be consistent about a standard for test since there will be growing number of these bug fixes moving forward. The argument I make here is for long term development rather than trying to avoid adding test for a specific bug :)
Merged to trunk, and cherry-picked to 0.10.0
LGTM and merged to both branches.

@kawamuray Could you rebase?

A couple of general comments:

1) Move DefaultClientSupplier into streams/processor/internals as it does not need to be public interface.
2) Could you also create a MockClientSupplier which uses the MockProducer and MockConsumer and add a unit test to validate that the clients are generated as expected?
A couple of minor comments, the rest looks good.
@ijuma comments addressed.
LGTM, will merge as soon as the tests pass.
LGTM, thanks!

@zhuchen1018 I think we're going in circles a bit. I'll leave some thoughts and if you want to discuss the topic more generally, then please start a mailing list thread. So here it goes:
- I think focusing on a language construct (`finally`) is perhaps the wrong way to think about it. Let's describe the issue as an interruptible method. It is a good idea to have a test that causes the method to be interrupted because this is a common source of bugs (examples are both the issue in this PR and in `ByteBuffer.allocate` where there were actually multiple bugs and PRs that you were involved with).
- When someone contributes a new feature, they contribute a bunch of tests and the reviewer tries to ensure that the test coverage is good. This is a bit of a subjective thing at the moment as we don't yet use coverage tools (and they have limits as well). Things will be missed, that's just the nature of it.
- When someone contributes a bug fix, there is evidence that a test would have been useful so we take that into account.
- When someone files a PR, it's worth being aware that reviewer time is also limited. Your PR is more likely to be merged faster if it fits the project guidelines.
- I hope that instead of a growing number of bug fixes, we write code with less bugs. We will see!

OK, that's all I have to say for now. :)
Tests passed locally.
Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Just a few minor comments.
@rajinisivaram : Thanks for the latest patch. LGTM. Just left a couple of minor comments.

@granders Since you've taken "class" out of the events in VerifiableProducer, maybe we should do the same for VerifiableConsumer?
@ijuma : Yes, your comments make sense. The patch LGTM then.
@hachikuji Good point - updated

@dpkp, we are on quite a tight deadline to get this into 0.10.0.0. Please let us know if you need any help getting this PR into shape. I've sketched a few of the changes suggested in the review comments locally to test them out (including the changes necessary to checkHC in the client) and I can clean them up and submit as a PR to your branch (you would then review and integrate into your branch if you were happy with them). The merged commit would still credit you as the author.
LGTM, thanks @Ishiihara!
LGTM, thanks @theduderog!

I'll make the changes, but generally I disagree w/ the style choices you're making. I think it should be remembered that underlying this is a _broken_ lz4 implementation. I wrote the code intentionally to look nasty when breaking lz4. I think it is a mistake to make breaking lz4 seem easy and clean. It should be gross and broken, just like the lz4 encoding it's doing...

But anyways, I'll make the changes :)

We're going to have to live with the broken implementation for a long time. There's no reason to make the code ugly on purpose. No-one will intentionally use the broken implementation, it's just there for compatibility reasons. Thanks for making the changes.
We also need to add a note to the `upgrade.html` file.
LGTM

See jira for discussion.

@granthenke I checked the other regex patterns in the EndPoint/BrokerEndPoint files and they are somewhat different. I think it's possible to create one pattern for all but not sure what was the reason we created different ones. If there is a need to have one pattern for all use-cases I'm happy to work on it but it might be better to create a separate JIRA/pull request for that.
